text: An unparalleled set of sheer mountains -- part of the Col Rockies. The peaks rise a challenging half mile and more of the valley -- wind-whipped snow mists over the mountai like a low fog. The tranquility is broken as a helicopter BLASTS into view, fighting the wind as it heads for the c of it all. Our CREDITS fly us past and through this magnificent rang There are sky-piercing peaks that slope up to a narrow, h pinnacle -- and others that are steel, straight-up approa to large plateaus. One of the mountains has a crystal lak top -- with a waterfall that drains from it and exits fro middle of a mountain wall. Nearby, an abandoned cable lad is bolted into the same wall, leading to the top.
We can see a man sitting in its doorway, looking out --
The glasses scan systematically, slowly -- to us, it look like nothing more than a field of gray and white.
Nothing yet.
The helicopter now circles this tallest mountain -- "The Tower", separated from a lower but equally formidable pea a chasm of two hundred feet -- that drops 3,500 feet belo

Spotter FRANK NEWELL (50s) scans the mountain wall.  MAGG DEIGHAN (30s) expertly pilots the helicopter through the winds. Both wear orange jackets identifying themselves as members of the Rocky Mountain Park Rescue Team.
Wait a minute -- there's Hal. (beat) And his date.

that's part of the smaller peak. HAL TUCKER (30s) and his "date", SUSAN COLLINS (20s), are decked out in climbing g Hal's aplomb suggests he's a veteran climber -- Susan's worried look shows she isn't. Hal and Susan huddle togeth both cold, but okay. Hal has a makeshift splint wrapped around his lower leg, and a slow burning flare in one han
Frank lowers his glasses -- Maggie struggles with the win
How do they look?
Hal, now aware of the copter, looks towards it, smiling - starts jerking off the flare.
He's signalling "okay."
Where's Gabe?
The POV dips down -- there's somebody climbing below, in orange rescue jacket.
Right where he's supposed to be.

This is GABE WALKER (30s). In spite of the cold and the s he's fearlessly, swiftly scaling the tower without safety lines, as if he's done it a hundred times. That's because has done it a hundred times. This is what Gabe lives for.

Gabe, almost there, finds a fingertip-width handhold at a length -- grabbing it, he pulls himself up on the ledge w move that's just a little tougher than chinning yourself doorjamb. Winded, Gabe slumps down next to the couple, an tries to light a cigarette. The lighter only sparks.
Excuse me -- I know you're my salvation, and all -- do you think you could rescue us before your smoke break?

Hal pulls out a box of wooden matches and lights one Boga style, one-handed with a thumbnail, cupping a hand to shi it against the wind. Gabe bends down for it -- a familiar routine. We know in a glance they've been friends for yea
Maybe you could tell me why I am rescuing you.
Basically -- I've fallen down, and I can't get up...
(into radio) Rescue One -- have located helpless climber, please prepare idiot line for transport, over --
THE HELICOPTER dips down towards the ledge -- no way can land there. Frank lowers a rescue wire to
who precariously swings out from the ledge to grab it -- wire is just out of reach. Hal grabs the radio.
Rescue One -- please remind me to tell you about the time I hauled your hero here down Mt. Huntington on my back, over --
(through radio) Hal, if I hear that story one more time, I'm making you limp down the entire three thousand feet, over --
Gabe finally grabs the line, secures it to a heavy piton, hammers it into the wall.
(to Susan) This guy showing you a good time?
swings over across to the facing mountain -- Maggie lands copter, in spite of the winds, on a small plateau. Frank out to secure the wire -- there's now a lifeline spanning chasm.

Gabe finishes anchoring the line in the rock -- he extinguishes his cigarette in the snow, and naturally, po the butt. Hal, propped up against the wall, expertly rigs seat harness around his legs -- Susan helps him get part around his splint, and Gabe clips it to the line.
Now, remember -- keep your arms and legs within the vehicle at all times --
(laughing) Fuck you --
With that, Hal pulls himself hand-over-hand across the sl line -- Hal makes a point of looking down --
is vertigo defined. Thirty five hundred feet straight dow You could stack the World Trade Center towers on top of e other and they'd still be shorter than this mountain is h However --

lets go of the overhead line and claps his hands to his f in mock horror -- he quickly whizzes down the last thirty of the line, where Frank catches him and pulls him out. H gets out of the harness, checks every stitch of it, signa thumbs-up, and sends it back.

Gabe, retrieves the harness on a small attachment line, a gives Susan a reassuring smile, but she's still, sensibly very scared. Gabe recovers the harness, rigs Susan into i and meticulously re-checks it.
Ready? (sees she's afraid) Did he tell you about the time he almost made it up Everest?
He said you gave him a bad oxygen mask --
Well, if he's bored you with that bullshit, then this has to be the best part of a bad date. Right?
Susan nervously laughs.
Ready?
(scared but tough) Okay --
Gabe starts to push her out on the line, but she grabs hi in a panic.
I can't --
Susan starts to tilt her head down -- Gabe gently takes h of her chin, turning her view up to face him.
Yes you can. (reassuring) You can do it. Don't look down.  The whole way across, don't look down. Look at me. Just keep looking at me -- and you'll be okay.
Susan looks at Gabe -- trying to be confident -- nods.
Sure?
Yeah. (beat) I have always depended on the kindness of Rangers.
Gabe grins and gently pushes her out. Susan tentatively p herself across -- then develops a rhythm, building speed
inching away in the harness, looking more confident now -
signalling "OK" -- "you're doing fine" --
thirty feet out, going fine --
holding the strap under Susan's left leg breaks --

The harness completely unravels all at once, its strands shoot through the clips -- what was a seat has become a t door in half a second -- as the harness shoots out from u her, Susan falls but grabs the harness strand --
is helpless, and can only watch as
too scared to breathe, dangles on the remaining strand of used to be the harness -- she sways from the wind and the of her own weight, her grip loosens --
that is supporting all of Susan's weight is being serious tested -- a single knot in the harness has caught there, it clearly won't last long --
moves back from the ledge.
(loud, in control) Hold on. I'm coming out to get you.
Gabe gently pulls himself up on the line, crosses his ank on it, and clips himself on with a three foot safety line Gabe starts smoothly, quickly pulling himself out, but --
is in trouble -- the bobbing of the line from Gabe's weig and the winds are making her lose her grip even more --
urgently pulls himself along the line faster, trying not shake the line. As he gets closer and closer to a terrifi Susan, his eyes lock on hers --
Keep looking at me. Hold on --
Gabe is only ten feet away from --
who stares at Gabe, petrified -- this focus is helping, b her strength is just about gone --
The knot has worked itself halfway through -- it doesn't any difference how tight she holds on to the harness, the harness itself is letting go --
who knows it and pulls himself the rest of the way, a lit faster, almost bridging the gap --
staring desperately at Gabe, holding on --
that's keeping Susan alive surrenders the knot -- it pass through, and
falls --
deliberately lets go of the main line and launches himsel at Susan --
miss --
Gabe's three foot safety line pulls taut, testing the lim of the line above as it yanks him back --
is just out of reach -- her hand is still stretched out, eyes still locked on
who can only look down, swaying helplessly on the wire as Susan's SCREAM starts --
Frank and Maggie look down in horror, but neither look as anguished as Hal --
falling -- falling -- falling -- looking very small again the vast mountain range --
from this height takes the longest nineteen seconds you c imagine --
twists from his safety line, spinning helplessly -- he wa to, but can't, shut his eyes --
Susan is gone. Her SCREAM, cut short, echoes -- the "safe harness spirals down after her like a carefree bird --
As the plane dips to land, Gabe can see a bird circling f below, over the same mountainous terrain.

sweating, panting, awake. It hasn't been that long since accident -- a year, to be exact -- but he looks older. He looks as if he's watched Susan Collins drop at least one hundred times. Gabe reels himself in as a STEWARDESS hand a glass of water.
Take this. (Gabe does) Afraid of flying?
Gabe shakes his head.
Falling.
Gabe, with no luggage, is at the small airport's only car rental counter, doing the paperwork for a RENTAL AGENT.
Midsize?
Any size, any color, any model.
How long will you be needing it?
(flat) Just under six hours.
You aren't wasting any time, are you?
Gabe turns and looks at
who is standing off to the side.
I knew you'd be coming by. Today.
Gabe's happy to see her -- but at the same time, he isn't She looks too good -- and she brings up quite a mixed bag memories. Maggie carves on a smile.
If you're in that much of a hurry, why don't you ride with me?
Maggie pilots the copter, heading out toward the mountain range. Gabe fiddles with some of the equipment inside. Bo grope for a way to start the conversation.
This is new...
It's a thermal scope -- picks up body heat of lost hikers --
Gabe flicks it on, looks at the total absence of heat as fly over the snow.
Still find the dead ones the old fashioned way, I guess.
So much for small talk. Gabe is clearly uneasy watching t mountains go by. Maggie breaks an awkward silence --
You could have said goodbye.
(shakes head) If I did, I'd have to listen to you tell me one more time that it wasn't my fault.

(angry) Today -- especially today -- you get to hear it again. The harness clip broke.  Cold stress -- one in a million equipment failure. You and Hal could have checked it from then till now and it still would have happened. (beat) You did everything right --
-- If I did everything right, Susan Collins would still be alive.

whizzes on to the Ranger station -- a small building by a country road. Not much activity outside of some ROOKIE CLIMBERS working out on a CLIMBING PRACTICE WALL. Maggie starts to land the copter, and as she does --
Do you really believe all that?  That it wasn't our fault?
Maggie slows the rotor, her eyes on the controls. Gabe's are locked on her.
(turns to Gabe) Yes. Yes, I do.
But she answered a half beat too slow. The helicopter tou ground.
I'm not sure what I wish more, Maggie. That you meant what you said, just now -- or that it were really true then.
Hal, wearing Sheriff's garb, storms towards Maggie's side the copter as the engine shuts off and the rotor dies.
Maggie, where the hell have you been? I've got two climbers out --
Gabe gets out of the copter, and Hal sees him for the fir time. Unlike the last time we saw them, neither man is gl see the other. Hal turns on Maggie.
Brett and Evan are up there again to jump off the spur. Their wives called twice. I want you in the air and I want them found before the storm system moves in. (Maggie hesitates) Now.
Maggie takes off as Gabe and Hal step away from the copte Gabe eyes Hal's uniform and almost -- not quite but almos laughs.
Christ. You're in charge of Rescue now?
There was a vacancy. Maybe you heard about it. The last guy lost his nerve and lit out of town.
Well, you're a better man than I am, Hal. Nothing rattles you.
The rookie climbers get off the practice wall to watch th faceoff. Gabe and Hal are one crack away from beating hel of each other. Frank heads over to defuse the confrontati
(steering Gabe away) Gabe! Long time, son -- why don't you come meet some of the new guys --
Good idea. Say, Hal? (beat) Why don't you come with me so we can show these rookies how to death-rig a woman properly?

That tears it -- Hal rushes Gabe and they pummel each oth until Frank and the others pull them apart, panting and bleeding.  Hal throws off the men holding him back -- but instead of going at Gabe again, Hal throws Gabe a set of keys.
Take the Bronco to where you're going. I've already been. Then go back to wherever it is you like to hide. And stay there.
Hal heads back into the office -- Gabe heads for the Bron
The Southwest regional center for printing and distributi currency. Hundreds of troops stand guard over the impress U.S. Treasury complex.
is at work -- the ROAR of its parts is deafening as it st out a plate design on huge sheets of paper -- we move in
which is moved by mechanical arm to a SLICER that razors bills apart -- it's moving too fast for us to see the denomination -- the cut bills are separated by --
that fire the bills down to a mechanical COUNTER that serializes, counts, bands and stacks them faster than any human could -- a HAND reaches to pick up a band --
are something a banker could work a lifetime without seei but are real nonetheless --  $5,000 bills, banded here in hundreds. The band is put back in the growing stack by

mid-thirties, a tough, imposing Treasury agent -- he rega the fortune piling up in front of him with only cold, professional interest. Travers is flanked by a trio of eq tough TREASURY AGENTS -- he turns to flunky DAVIS (20s). clear who's in charge of protecting the money here, and w in charge of counting it.
Tell Wright the San Francisco shipment is ready.
(phone already out) Right away, Mr. Travers.
As Davis dials we move to --
of WALTER WRIGHT (50s), comptroller of currency -- his demeanor suggests he's in control, and used to keeping it way.
(into phone) Good -- good. I'll be right down.
As Wright gets up from his desk, though, we hear in the o office --
You can't go in there --
Watch me.
KURT MATHESON (30s) bursts into the office, trailed by Wright's flustered SECRETARY.
Walter Wright? (flashes badge) Matheson. FBI. We need to talk.

has now been packed into a trio of metal briefcases -- te thousand $5,000 bills. Travers shuts the cases in turn, a locks each with an electronic key card, triggering a FLAS RED LIGHT on the locks as he does. A uniformed PILOT show behind Travers as he cuffs the cases to the hands of the other agents.
We'll be fueled and ready in ten minutes, Mr. Travers.
(an order) Be ready in five.
Go ahead and take ten. We'll need the time.
Travers looks up at Matheson, who has just arrived with Wright. Travers is instantly furious at the challenge to authority.
(flashes badge) Matheson. FBI.
(looking down at it) Your parents must be proud. (to Wright) What the fuck is this about?
Small problem with the shipment, Travers. (to Matheson) Tell him what you just told me.
Matheson draws out a file and hands it to Travers.
We got word that somebody's been observing your currency shipments -- this load, the $5,000s -- over the last three deliveries.

(laughs) There isn't a hell of a lot anyone can do but observe. (beat) This is the most protected shipment we've got -- and the most useless for a thief. Those bills aren't in circulation. You think five thousand dollar bills are easy to pass? Who the fuck would try?
Matheson hands Travers a folder.
This guy might.
We look over Travers' shoulder at the photos, which are a blurry, all blown up from different surveillance pictures and all of them show ERIC QUALEN.
Who is he?

(patient) His name's Eric Qualen. One of the East German spies who got shut out by the reunification. The CIA issued an inter-agency warning about him right after the wall came down. He's got nowhere to go and nothing to lose. He's also got the international connections to get rid of bills like these -- and he's probably desperate enough to try for them. Fifty million bucks buys a lot of sanctuary.
Could you get to the part where I'm supposed to care?
(shows him more photos) We had two agents monitoring him. These two -- Gleason and Quinones. Their last report said he was going to try to take this shipment.
(turning away) Thanks for the tip. But I've got work to do.
(stopping him) Did I say "last" report? I think I did. I mean last fucking report. These guys have vanished.

You have my sympathy, but -- (exasperated) There's a reason we do things this way, all right? Armored cars can be hijacked. Trains can be derailed. But nobody can get to us in flight. The only time this is on the ground is at the mint, or on the Presidio runway in San Francisco. Either way, someone would have to shoot his way past a couple of thousand guards.
Matheson still isn't convinced.

If you're worried about an inside job, forget it. I checked the plane from top to bottom an hour ago. And these three are my best against. Even if one of them did go skydiving, they wouldn't get far. Each case has an electronic tracer with a range of one hundred miles.
Travers pulls a tracking device about the size of a watch out of his jacket pocket. The small screen shows three re blips at rest -- matching the three currency cases.
(facing down Matheson) I haven't lost a bill in eight years. And I'm not scrubbing this shipment because you scare easily.
(an easy smile) Who said anything about stopping the shipment? (beat) I've been tracking Qualen for almost a year. If he pulls something, I want to be in on the party.
Travers, angry, turns to Wright. Wright clearly doesn't l this either, but is resigned to it.
This is cleared from the top, Travers. Matheson will accompany you on the flight to San Francisco. (beat) Show him every professional courtesy.
Travers turns back to a smiling Matheson, looking like he rather kill him instead, as we --
is being buffeted by storm winds and a light snow -- Magg struggles hard with the controls, but --
Visibility is near zero. Maggie keys the radio.
Rescue One to base, over.
Rescue One -- have you sighted them? Over --
Negative, Hal -- storm's already moving in -- I can't see them, and winds are too strong to stay up here -- over --

Rescue One -- abort. They'll be all right. Brett and Evan are dumb enough not to log in, but they're smart enough to have storm gear. Head back to base. (not unkindly) Maybe you can catch Gabe before he leaves. Over.
I don't think he's planning a long visit, Hal. (back to business) Rescue One heading back to base, over and out.
banks a 180 to fly back -- we can see over the horizon th the storm is moving in fast.

We can hear Maggie's helicopter flying off overhead -- ca inside the cave are BRETT and EVAN, both 20s, both shiver amid their gear -- backpacks, cooking stuff -- and parach These are Colorado rock jocks -- thrillseekers who'll try anything if the odds are strong enough they'll die in the process.
(freezing) Way to check the weather, Brett.
(shivering yet macho) Hey. If it were easy, it wouldn't be worth d-doing.
The DC-9 cruises over increasingly mountainous, remote terrain.

who looks tense -- we MOVE AROUND the cabin and find two relaxed Treasury agents are dozing on the opposite side o plane, their arms chained to the currency cases. Matheson edgy. Another AGENT offers some condescending reassurance
Just enjoy the view, huh? (Matheson says nothing) Relax. I mean, what could happen in the air?
Matheson turns back to his window and looks down --
is covered with snow -- the jet's shadow moves sleekly an plainly over it. But after a moment we see -- -- another jet's shadow on the ground, coming up fast!
reacts this and shifts his look upward to --
is flying a parallel course to the Treasury jet, and is j one hundred yards away. Close enough to see Eric Qualen's in one of the windows.
Matheson stands -- Travers has noticed the plane by now t and gets out of his seat as the other agents react.
(to other agents) Stay put! Don't panic, goddammit!
Travers moves into
where the pilot seems nervous, but oddly, not frightened.
He's coming in too slow.
(cool) No -- we're going too fast, and we're too high up. Push flaps forward twenty degrees and drop to five thousand feet.
Matheson is out of his seat, pistol drawn. Seems a little under the circumstances.
(to agent) You got any rifles?
Forward compartment -- left side --
Matheson rushes through a curtain to the area between the cabin and the cockpit and pulls open a closet door. To hi horror, he finds inside not rifles, but
who we'll recognize as the missing FBI agents from the ph Matheson showed Travers.
backs up in horror -- and he sees Travers calmly coming o the cockpit. Rattled, Matheson pulls his gun on Travers. Travers looks dumbfounded -- then angry.
What the hell are you doing --
Checked the plane from top to bottom, huh? You fucker -- (clicks hammer back) Put your hands behind your head! It's over!
Travers puts his hands out and walks forward -- slowly, backing Matheson into the cabin. Not in surrender, but as he's calming a nutcase. The other agents see this and don know which way to jump.
Calm down -- give the gun to me --
(to other agents) There's a couple of dead bodies in the front compartment -- they're FBI agents --
He's losing it --
They now think Matheson is crazy too -- he looks nuts -- other agents move behind him. Matheson gets even more fra and point his gun at them.
Goddamn it! Don't you see what he's doing! He's hijacking the fucking shipment! (back to Travers) Don't make me shoot you!
The other two agents get behind Matheson and rapidly disa him. Travers pulls out his gun with a slow, leisurely mov
Don't make me laugh.

Travers FIRES his gun three times, one for each agent's chest -- the agents are cut down, realizing too late what happened. A fourth SHOT knocks Matheson over a seat as if been kicked. Travers puts his gun away and puts on a radi headset as he goes to a window.
(to mouthpiece) Move into position.
maneuvers over the DC-9 -- and holds steady above it.
The stone reads "Susan Collins -- 1965 - 1991". It's surrounded by wreaths -- one of which has an old snapshot her attached to it. Mementos sent on the first anniversar her death.
brushes some of the falling snow away from the marker. He down his flowers and pauses for a moment -- then gets int Bronco and drives away.
Gabe looks out the window at the countryside he used to b in. He's wondering if he still does.
Qualen's jet is now flying parallel to, and slightly abov the Treasury jet. The door in Qualen's jet is open, and w our first good look at --

-- Qualen, who is also wearing a headset radio and is wir to a safety line in the jet. He's lowering a thick steel down to the Treasury jet. Qualen is as deadly as advertised -- 150 mph winds are te at him through the open door, but he is unfazed and unfrightened.
is also wired to a safety line by his own jet's open door
(into radio) More -- more -- keep it coming --
Qualen's jet lowers the cable into the Treasury jet -- it looks like an Air Force midair refuelling -- difficult an dangerous. After about thirty feet of line is lowered --
-- takes it in and clips it to a ring at the top of the j doorway.
(into radio) Locked on. Move into lateral position.
The pilot, KRISTEL, is a woman. Her skill, like her hard beauty, can be measured in a glance: she's a lot calmer t her counterpart in the Treasury plane.
Moving into lateral position.
Qualen's jet lowers itself, banking to the side -- the Treasury jet raises itself. Both are now flying side by s with the cable serving as a thirty foot bridge.
Travers, unclipped from his safety line, cautiously goes the cockpit. The pilot, nervous, struggles with the contr
We're right on the edge of the storm -- let's move it.
Travers pulls the two dead FBI agents out of the compartment -- one is dressed in a flying suit like the p one in a suit like Travers.
This isn't going to work -- Wright will suspect something.

So what. He'll sift though a plane that went down in a storm -- (gestures to bodies) -- find enough pulverized bone for six men heroically killed in the line of duty -- (finds three suitcases) -- and just enough of the right kind of ash.
Travers opens one of the cases, which is identical to the others -- except that it's full of one dollar bills. He's thought of everything.
We get twenty-one gun funerals and they write off fifty million. It's perfect, as long as you hold the plane steady -- so concentrate.
Travers moves back into the cabin.

We can now see four other passengers. All are fit and arm HELDON and RYAN are seated, while KYNETTE and DELMER, rea help with the transfer, are on the opposite side of the d from a very impatient Qualen.
(into radio) Travers -- hurry it up.
Travers, now in a harness like the one seen earlier -- un the money cases from the agents.
(into radio) On my way.
Travers steps back into the cockpit and flips a toggle sw over and LED --
starts counting down from 2:00 -- 1:59 -- 1:58 --
Even in the last minute, the storm's gotten worse -- the is flying right into the blackest center of it. The pilot looks more panicked than ever.

That charge is going to blow both engines -- the plane'll go down like a rock, so clip yourself on to the end of the cable with the money as soon as I get over. (an afterthought) And make sure you bring the right cases.
Travers heads back into the cabin and hooks his harness t cable between the planes.
(into the headset) Dip the plane. I'm coming over.
Qualen's jet dips down so there's a sharp incline -- Trav starts the slide down, zipping in seconds across into
where he's pulled in and unclipped by Qualen.
(shouting over the wind) Why didn't you send the money over?
(shouting too) Somehow, I didn't think you'd have waited for me if I'd sent it first.
Qualen smiles in reply. No. Maybe he wouldn't.
The pilot locks the controls and rushes back to the cabin
The pilot gathers the cases and uses their cuffs to attac them to the cable -- but as he steps past the bodies of -
Matheson's eyes open -- he's not dead yet.
The pilot clicks the last of the three cases onto the cab and is about to put his harness on -- but behind him, Mat shakily crawls to his feet, draws his gun, and SHOOTS the pilot in the back twice.
drops out of the plane, flailing -- if he's screaming, we can't hear it over the HOWLING of the storm --
Qualen and Travers are watching the whole plan unravel --
(shouting to cockpit) Get underneath the jet! The cases will slide over!
Qualen's jet sharply dips down and the cases start to sli over -- but at the same time --
Matheson, groggy, holds onto the doorway and FIRES a full from his automatic at Qualen's jet -- and
are destroyed as the charge DETONATES --
As promised, the Treasury jet is now plummetting as if it no wings at all, levelling the angle between the planes - cases dangle precariously on the wire --
(shouting) Lower! Get underneath it!
Matheson struggles to the cockpit and gets behind the con -- as if that's going to do any good --
Qualen's jet is deliberately racing the disabled Treasury down, but it's hopeless -- there's no way to get undernea the falling jet long enough for the cases to slide over.
isn't quite panicked. Yet.
It's dragging us down! Disconnect the cable!
Heldon and Ryan try to do just that, but the cable is taut -- there's no way to loosen the clip on the door --
dive down faster at an ever steeper angle, over the edge the Colorado mountain range --
-- the clip on the door finally breaks --
-- the Treasury jet drops as Qualen's jet, trailing the c and the money, sharply shoots upward --
makes a one point landing nose first into the wilderness, cartwheeling into a FIREBALL!
The sound of the EXPLOSION, muffled in the wind, far-off, audible, drives Hal outside -- he's alert, but can't see anything in the murk of the storm --
levels off the plane, but it's still in trouble --
struggle to reel in the cable, because --
The money cases are still, barely, holding on, the cuffs caught on the broken clip at the end --
aren't even bothering with the electric winch, they're dragging it in hand over hand -- but --
-- the cases, torn by the wind, work their way loose one time and drop -- one -- two -- three -- into the snowy mountains below!
Heldon and Ryan clamp the door shut as Qualen angrily att Travers --
tries to bring the plane up, but can't -- the fuel guage needle is dropping fast --
is pouring out fuel through a dozen bullet holes -- one o engines sputters to a stop.
The plane is now just skirting the mountain tops, and is being battered by storm winds -- Kristel aims it for what looks like the flattest, longest mountain top --
Kynette and Ryan grab Qualen and Travers to separate them all strap in, because
is going down -- it just tops the edge of a precipice and the ground level --
-- the problem is, the ground itself isn't level, it tilt down towards another edge five hundred yards distant -- i plane keeps skidding, it'll go over the edge --
sleds down at an angle, skipping over rocks -- -- through trees -- -- tearing off a wing --
Kristel rides the stick only out of habit -- nothing she is going to matter now --
The men are jolted around -- windows IMPLODE as Kynette t to protect a bag of what is obviously explosives --
rips downhill through a wooded area like a runaway train -- the second wing is sheared off by trees --
is coming up fast -- but
wrenches to a sudden halt, the fuselage intact.

or what's left of it has stopped several feet short of th edge -- we can see why: the steel cable, trailing from th cargo door, has lashed itself around a half dozen trees, acting as a tripwire to stop the plane.
Quiet. All are dazed but, outside of superficial cuts, unhurt. Kristel moves out of the cockpit, looking around.
So much for phase one. (to Travers) Now what?
She speaks for all of them -- especially a still-seething Qualen. Travers pulls out the tracer monitor for the case The tracer screen shows three distinct blips -- the trace have survived the fall.
Now -- we call the police.
Hal, agitated, paces in the main office -- Frank, unconce puts a coat hanger and some aluminum foil on a little TV drag in the fading signal of a Broncos game.
Look -- I know there's a storm, but that wasn't thunder.
(unconcerned) Hal, when you've been in this line as long as I have --
The station's scanner radio barks to life.
(panicky) Mayday -- mayday -- downed DC-3 --  mayday --
Hal runs to the radio and keys the mike.
Rocky Mountain Rescue -- come in, mayday --
Kristel is on the radio, as Travers and Qualen hang back. Kristel's voice is panicked but she can't suppress a grin
Downed charter flight alpha-charlie-niner-- (keys mike to "garble" transmission) -- dead, seven seriously wounded, acknowledge --

Come on -- tourists take this trail.
Qualen pokes Hal with the gun -- he moves on ahead.
It's getting dark rapidly -- Gabe has scaled a rock forma so he has a view of the rest of the summit --
Gabe slowly looks along the trees of the summit -- looks pretty ordinary to us, but something must have caught Gab eye, because he swings back to look at one tree. With bro branches on top.
climbs down from his rock perch and rushes toward the tre
This "expedition" reaches the top -- Hal is in the lead, Qualen just inches behind. Qualen shoves Hal forward.
Is this it?
Yeah. This is it.
Good. Get out of the way.
Travers takes out the tracer and starts following the bli

frantically rushes around, looking for the case -- he spo crater of snow, rushes to it and starts digging. Even bel the snow, the tracer's blinking red light is glowing and visible. Gabe laughs as he digs it out.
has his eyes glued to the tracer monitor, which shows the is nearby.
(smiling) This way.
Qualen shines a light -- all of them push their way throu the trees.
is excited now -- he can't even wait for Qualen's flashli he intuitively races through the trees, dividing his atte between his surroundings and
which shows he's practically on top of the case -- finall
shoves his way through some small pines -- he can see the blinking of the red tracer light ahead through the branch
(calling behind) It's over here!
Travers shoves his way through the branches, and heads fo light -- but something's wrong -- Qualen comes up behind Travers and shines the light on

cute, if hastily constructed, stands with a five-pebble s as well as Douglas' cap, in a clearing. The still blinkin still operable tracer is now the nose of the snowman. The is leaned up against it. Travers runs over to the case, furious, and opens it. It' empty -- except for a single $5000 bill. Travers picks it up -- scrawled on the margin is "LET'S TRADE."
(incredulous) He's still alive. (furious) He's still alive! (to Qualen and the others) He can't be far away -- spread out!
Qualen, Kynette, Delmer and Krystel fan out into the wood each with a flashlight and a fun. Ryan, however, straps o nightfinder goggles and runs out without a flashlight.
(to Hal, brandishing gun) Put your hands on your head.
watches the chaos with a grin from a slightly elevated va point -- he can see the flashlight beams, all headed in t wrong direction. But he doesn't see

With these goggles, light is amplified a thousandfold -- isn't one of those infra-red, thermo-blob jobs -- it look more like day for night photography. Even starlight is en for Ryan to run easily through the thick woods -- and he' going in the right direction.
begins climbing down to level ground so he can circle clo to where Travers is holding Hal -- before he can get far
looks up, and can clearly see Gabe climbing down the smal rock, twenty yards distant --
smiles, looking macabre under the goggles, and opens fire
is startled as the bullets impact inches over his head -- jumps the last ten feet to the ground and is running even he hits the ground -- more bullets hit where Gabe was a split second ago --
chases Gabe, easily maneuvering through the trees --
runs too, trying to dodge Ryan's continuing fusillades -- knows this territory, but to him, it's still pitch dark - stumbles, and rams against trees --
keeps coming up behind, closing the hap, Gabe's bright fo just ahead --
comes out of the trees and finds he is on another part of summit. All that's beneath him is
-- a sudden, sloping plunge down a field of ice. No escap route here -- anything that goes down this slide is going the way to the ground far below.
is driven forward by a fresh burst of bullets -- he dives the edge of the ice field and ducks behind a boulder -- t sole source of cover.
Kristel, Qualen and Kynette, having heard the gunshots, a now rushing to Gabe's position --
almost casually emerges from the woods. He can see there nowhere for Gabe to have gone -- except behind the boulde walks toward it as if he had all the time in the world.

fumbles in his backpack and pulls out something from the Douglas exhibit -- an ancient flare that looks like a can sterno. Gabe pulls out his lighter and tries to light it resists and looks like a dud, but finally it catches, and it ignites Gabe heaves it over the boulder at Ryan --
arcs over the boulder to fully ignite, turning everything into a blinding, agonizing flash of white --
SCREAMS, putting one hand over the goggles, trying to rip off --
bolts out from behind the boulder to rush him --
instantly aware of what Gabe's doing, blindly shoots, fan out in a semi-circle as he gets the goggles off --

just runs straight ahead to Ryan, getting to him before t machine gun field of fire can intersect his path -- Gabe tackles Ryan as he manages to get the goggles off -- both fall to the ground, and -- The machine gun CLATTERS away, landing on the edge of the just out of reach -- Ryan, now recovered from the blindin flash, pulls an ice axe out of a pack sheath and swings i Gabe -- Gabe rolls away in time, and gets to the machine grabbing it -- But Ryan dives for Gabe, slamming into him the force of it knocks the machine gun loose -- it skips the ice slope -- but the momentum of Ryan's hit also carr both Gabe and Ryan over the edge, onto --
Gabe and Ryan both tumble over the edge and start sliding down, Ryan face first on his stomach, Gabe head first and his back -- both are in immediate agony, because
-- it's covered with razor sharp, irregular ridges, both and small, that slice through clothing and shred skin as pick up speed --
The edge and a five thousand foot drop are less than a hu yards away --
Ryan flails and SCREAMS as the ice gashes him from underneath -- Gabe, however, manages to flip over and to side -- he lunges on top of Ryan and rides him down like bobsled --
is coming up too fast --

tries to maintain his perch on Ryan, who is SCREAMING and yet used to the idea of being a human sled -- he isn't remaining still enough to provide a smooth ride -- Gabe frantically reaches behind to Ryan's wrist to get the ice trailing from a wrist strap, but Ryan's arm is thrashing threatening to toss off the axe --
Qualen, Kristel and Kynette arrive at the lip, and look d incredulous --
Gabe and Ryan, accelerating, have almost reached the edge

finally grabs the ice axe, pulling it off Ryan's wrist -- as they reach the precipice edge, Gabe loops the axe to h wrist and swings toward the ice with everything he's got The axe's scythe-like blade catches on the ice, right at lip of the precipice -- Gabe is wrenched to a painful hal suspended over the drop, as what's left of Ryan, still SCREAMING, shoots over the edge -- Gabe unhooks the axe, and gets another handhold. Gabe use axe to climb further down the ice to some rock -- finding easier hand holds, he quickly disappears into the darknes
look down -- Ryan's death scream is still echoing. Qualen furious -- Gabe has escaped with the second case.
(to Kynette) Follow him!
Kynette shines his flashlight below, illuminating the lon frozen streak of blood on the ice.
(gestures with light) After you.

The expedition has holed up here for the night -- Travers Qualen look upset. Things aren't going as well as they'd hoped. Kristel tries to get some candy out of a vending machine that's obviously empty. Kynette saws at some camp with a distinctive knife -- the handle is a set of brass knuckles. Delmer guards Hal, who is bound, and seated by souvenir photo stand.
Well -- look at the bright side. (beat) At least you've only got to make the split five ways now.

Gabe confidently drops down onto a large ledge that juts from the wall -- obviously familiar territory for him. Th ledge leads to a small, enclosed cave. Gabe takes out his penlight and shines it -- but the light looks dim. Batter are low. Gabe pockets it, flicks his lighter and goes in
in the flickering light, we can see that no one has been here for a while -- snow, dust, rocks -- but we should al recognize this from the photo seen earlier as Gabe, Maggi Hal's hangout.
smiles with the memories -- then his face brightens with memory in particular. Gabe rushes to a corner of the cave opens a rock-lid to a hiding place.
Please still be there -- oh, please --

Gabe reaches in the stash and finds an ancient half-full of Jack Daniels. The first thing to go right all day. Gab uncaps it and gratefully gulps down a double shot. Peace, last. Gabe smiles and leans against the wall, closing his -- but he's startled instantly by a SCREECH -- Gabe's eye shoot open -- An aggressive rat scurries toward him on the floor. Gabe grabs a rock and CLOBBERS the rat off-screen, ending screeches with one blow. Gabe's face first registers disgust -- then an idea. Then real disgust. Sighing, Gabe pulls out a pocket knife and opens the blade.
Gabe takes the now cooked rat carcass -- properly skinned butchered -- off his knife blade. We can see from flicker shadows that a small fire is now burning in a cave -- we pull back to see

which is built out of small bundles of $5,000 bills. It's to say that something like $500,000 is going up in smoke, the fire's dying down. Gabe tosses a fresh band of bills the flame. Gabe cools the knife in some snow, saws off a leg, and chews unhappily.
(mouth full) Mmm. Just like -- chicken.
Gabe sparingly washes the bite down with a taste of Jack Daniel. It's going to have to last him. He has an entire to get through.
The first rays of the sun start to poke through the mount It's stopped snowing -- the storm seems to be letting up.
Very quiet in here. Frank is snoring, slumped over the ra Maggie is wide awake and obviously hasn't slept -- her attention is fixed out the window.
The gauge is still flying around, but clearly shows that winds are slowing.
Wright is coiled at his desk, tense. Ten empty styrofoam coffee cups -- and dark rings under Wright's eyes -- make clear he hasn't slept. Wright's assistant bursts in.
We've got a fix on the plane, sir -- we're getting a reading on the flight recorder tracer --
Any visual? Any radio contact?
Not yet --
(heading to the door) Get the copters ready. We take off in three minutes.
The winds are still too strong --
Sorry to hear it. We're still going. The plane might be intact.
Wright drags the protesting Davis out the door.
Sir --
Shut up. That fifty million isn't coming out of my pension.

Travers, Qualen and the rest of the expedition head out o shack, a little groggy. Odds are no one got much sleep. Travers shoves Hal toward a sketchy "YOU ARE HERE" map of mountain range, and hands him the tracer monitor.
Still interested in staying alive?
Hal matches the monitor to the map -- the blip is higher
(pointing to map) It's up here. Somewhere on the Tower. There's a way to cross over to the top in about half a day.
Show me.
Travers shoves Hal forward -- the others follow.
From about fifty yards off, someone watches Hal lead the away from the shack.
They're heading toward the opposite edge. An easy way down.
are crouched in the woods. Brett, gun in hand, has no ide far out of his league he is. Evan looks like he's having second thoughts, but he can't hack down now.
I'll cut around this side, and wind up in front. You come up behind them -- quietly. And we've got 'em.
Brett -- they've got five guns --
And you can collect them all after I get the drop on 'em. Let's get moving.
Brett, automatic held high, circles off through the woods Evan reluctantly lopes off toward his assignment.

Gabe pulls his jacket on -- reversed, with the grey linin out, so the orange won't make him so easy to spot -- and starts out towards the facing Tower -- his route, clearly going to be along the rock wall. It's relatively sheer, b there are shelves cut into it to make walking easy.
races quietly through the woods in a parallel path with H who's guiding the hang. Brett circles around ahead of the waiting. Before he can jump out --
hiding ahead in the trees and rocks.
makes eye contact with Brett, realizes what he's doing, a shakes his head as violently as he dares -- no, don't --
gives Hal a confident wink in response, then pounces in f of the gang, gun held high.
End of the line!
Travers, Delmer, Kristel and Kynette are startled, but do immediately comply. This throws Brett off his stride.
(nervous now) You heard me! Drop the guns!
Travers smiles and steps closer to Brett. The others walk in front of Hal. Travers actually laughs.
"End of the line"? That's classic. (beat) You've got style. So, I'm going to give you a three-count to figure out how to turn the safety off.
Brett doesn't even look down -- he responds by FIRING a s burst over Travers' head.
Nice try. I've got one of these at home. Now drop 'em.
All drop their guns -- Brett, unfortunately, realizes at same time we do --
Hey -- where's the other guy --
(shouting) Brett, behind you!
Too late -- Brett can only twist around half way before -

easily mows down Brett with his machine gun, riddling him at least thirty rounds at close range. Brett falls dead i the snow. Qualen walks up to Brett's corpse, blood steami the reddening snow, and kicks it over.
Gabe, reacting to the sound of the machine gun fire, clim up, but there's nothing he can do --
and the others pick up their guns.
(turning to face Hal) Time to --
Travers sees that Hal is gone -- he's escaped in the confusion.
runs like his ass is on fire and practically collides wit Evan, who is more panicked than ever.
What are we going to do --
You came up here to jump the spur -- (pulls Evan's chute out of his pack) This'd be a great time to do it.
(panicked) But --
(quick) Listen -- they don't know you're up here -- I'll draw their fire, you've got to make the jump and get help.
I don't -- I -- uh --
(exasperated, grabs chute) Unless you want to do it the other way around?
Evan snatches the parachute and runs off. Hal, wasting no time, runs in the opposite direction, deliberately making much noise as he can, slapping branches, stomping on rock
runs into the woods -- Qualen and Kristel, hearing Hal's retreat, run after him.  But Travers stops for a second - has spotted
in the snow -- not unlike a neon arrow.
runs in the direction of the footprints and quickly close gap between him and
who tries to pull on the chute and run at the same time - it's not easy. Evan closes one of the three buckles -- bu
bursts out of the woods and runs up right behind him --
in the meantime, get behind Hal in a clearing -- Kristel over his head.
Stop!
Hal, caught again, freezes in his tracks.
is still up and running -- he dodges Travers' fire, weavi through trees, getting the second buckle closed -- he see edge, just ahead, and puts on an extra burst of speed --
does likewise, still firing -- his clip runs out, but thi only buys Evan an extra few seconds --
is a rock formation that just out like a diving board -- runs like hell to the edge of it --
is right behind him, and has slapped a fresh clip in plac but before he can shoot --
dives off the edge and clasps the third buckle --
is directly below a few hundred feet -- looking up, he th Evan has made it -- but
throws himself down, aims quickly but carefully, and FIRE twenty rounds towards Evan's falling figure --
Evan LAUGHS -- he hasn't been hit --
Come on -- wait till you're out of range -- don't pull it yet --
Several seconds pass -- Evan is now several hundred feet and apparently out of firing range --
stops firing -- but doesn't seem unhappy at all.
LAUGHS more and pulls the D-ring -- the parachute billows open, inflating --
which has been shredded by bullets that hit the pack -- a quickly as it inflates, it deflates through dozens of holes -- whatever resistance is left vanishes as the cano collapses.

exhilaration turns to panic as he frantically pulls on th chute's guide lines -- but the more he does this, the fas the chute caves in -- he SCREAMS as the chute finally giv way and plummets right past
who is powerless to do anything but watch --
falls the long, full five thousand feet, desperately, uselessly, pulling in the lines of the tattered chute unt he's tangled in it like a shroud --
turns away -- he can't watch Evan hit bottom -- he grimac and looks up with absolute hate at
who doesn't see Gabe -- he's laughing at Evan's desperati which ends as his death scream is cut off. Hal is led over to the spur, with the other gang members behind him. Hal looks as angry as Gabe.
Was that Walker?
No such luck. (to Hal, smiling) Cheer up. Everyone should die in a spot this beautiful.
who has heard this and is shaking with fury.
(quietly) Don't worry. You will.
On top, Hal reluctantly leads the gang away -- below, we see Gabe start out on a parallel path along the ledges.
Winds or not, Maggie is untying the helicopter's rotor fr the bolts on the helipad. Frank, who has obviously just awakened, rushes out of the station.
Maggie -- what are you doing --
I'm going to go nuts if I sit here one more hour.
Still a little breezy out, Mag --
Maggie gets into the helicopter and starts the rotor.
(over engine's whine) You coming?
Frank hesitates, but climbs in the other side. The helico lifts off and heads toward the mountain range.

The next obstacle Hal is leading the gang through is a buttress -- a large, stark boulder formation -- that lays between the mountain they've just come from, and the near mountain to it: the Tower. This is lower down from the summit -- it's solid and treeless. Hal and the rest of the expedition is totally exposed as climb in single file up to the top. Terrain is flat enoug that the climb amount to an uphill run on all fours.
Hal leads the gang forward -- and keeps casting anxious glances back at them. And beyond them. Travers notices th
Forget about it. He's smart, but he's not invisible.
Hal looks back. Travers is right. There's absolutely no w Gabe can come up behind them without being seen.

where the bluff meets a tree-lined plain. Gabe, in hiding watches Hal and the others go up. No, he can't follow the the bluff's side without being seen. But Gabe moves close the bluff's base -- Gabe shoves through some trees to the beginning of
A crevice runs the entire length and breadth of the bluff
pulls out his ancient binoculars, and scans the crack.

Starting with an outside view, we can see that the crevic runs all the way up, and through, the bluff -- but it's a zig-zag, not a straight line. Picture a mine shaft designed by a madman. The crack move upward, then erratically to the side, then straight up ag The width of the crack is uneven, ranging from six inches six feet. And that's just how it looks on the outside. There's no telling what the interior is like. Gabe turns the binoculars to the inside of the crack. It' hard to see much -- it's very, very dark. But it looks as the crack goes all the way through the bluff, as well as the way up it. On this route, Gabe can tunnel through the mountain instead of going up the side.
puts away the binoculars and wedges himself into the crac starting the long process of going up -- and through -- t mountain formation.

A frenzy of activity, as several dozen Treasury agents si through the snow for the wreckage of the CT-39, some taki photos, some taking videotapes, some putting the pieces i bags for analysis. Many bags. Many small bags.
The Treasury plane has been completely pulverized by the and its subsequent explosion -- there are few pieces here aren't charred, and fewer still that are any larger than paperback book.
unhappily walks through the carnage and past agents gathe up the plane, to a harried crash specialist from the FAA ROSS STUART (40s) -- who is organizing the debris.
What can you confirm?
Well, sir -- it crashed. That, I can confirm. (condescending) We've been here just about one hour. These events take months to analyze. So if you'll excuse me --
He walks away -- but Wright, pissed, spins him around.

No, I don't think I will. The reason the FAA pays you is to exercise your vast, amazing knowledge of these "events". So I expect you to come up with some stunning insights, something a slow-witted fuck like me hasn't already observed. (gesturing to wreckage) One: it didn't blow up in mid-air, because the debris isn't widely dispersed. But was there a bomb on board that could have disabled it? I wonder. (pointing back) Two: There wasn't an attempted landing. Otherwise, there'd be debris to the east of the wreckage, where the plane was coming from. Did it come straight down? That's got me scratching my head too. (gesturing back to wreckage) And three: the flight recorder's tracer led us here in the first place. So where is the goddamn thing? That one's got me all aflush with curiosity.
(a little cowed) You'll be the first to know.
Oh, I believe you.
Wright storms off as agents delicately handle debris.

A vista. From this point, you can see everything else in mountain range. The only thing left that's taller is the Tower, a hundred yards away. Between the two mountains li drop of a mere four thousand feet. Hal has led the rest of the gang up to the edge. Travers approaches him, furious.
I thought you said there was an easy way across.
There is. You might not like it much.
Hal points
A steep two hundred yard downhill climb leads to a wire t bridges the two mountains. The same wire we saw at the beginning -- left behind from Susan Collins' botched resc
Of course -- we'll have to do it hand over hand. Seems I forgot my harness. Sorry.
Don't be. Lead on.
Hal is surprised to see Kynette pull a harness out of his -- the one Travers used earlier. Disappointed, Hal leads downward climb, looking several hundred yards to
running up, and through, the bluff, coming out on this si
registers a thought -- will he? -- then dismissal. Nah. H couldn't.
Gabe is sweating, straining in the dark, climbing up -- t be a good spot to pull back and take in the view, except

-- there's nowhere to pull back to. There's about two inc of clearance between Gabe's chest and the rock, and about same between his back and the rock. To the right, there i light. At all. To the left, there's no light. Even above, there is no light, because the crack isn't straight -- na isn't that obliging -- it zig-zags up. Gabe is well withi mountain rock. Nothing could be closer to being buried al Gabe snakes through a spot where the crack goes straight he takes out his penlight and turns it on --
even this dim light reveals scores of bats hanging on the wall, surrounding him, up and down, left and right --
is stuck somewhere between nausea and the realization tha he's made a big mistake.
I didn't need to see that. I really didn't.
Gabe cuts the light and slithers up through the dark.
Maggie and Frank are flying low and fast, over treetops a snow -- both are intently staring down --
is nothing but empty wilderness. But a BUZZER goes off --
turn their attention to the helicopter's heat scope, whic shows something alive beneath them.
Got 'em -- they're under the trees --
Maggie smiles and slows the copter over a clearing --
touches down. Maggie is out of it before the rotor has st turning, running into the trees.
Hal! Gabe!
Maggie runs into the trees, headlong into

that are preying on -- a body. A pair of legs are gruesom sticking out from the feast. One wolf turns to SNARL at M -- but Frank runs up and pulls a gun from a holster. Frank aims high and FIRES twice to scare the pack -- the wolves run off. Maggie goes to the body -- Frank holds he back, but she goes ahead anyway, worried it might be Gabe
as she examines the body --
It's Evan. (she stands, looks up) Parachute failed.
(not unkindly) Damn fool. Why would anybody try that in the middle of a storm.
Why would anybody try at all. (sighs) Get the bag.

Gabe has a quick climbing rhythm now. He pulls himself up his hands, then braces his body with his back, and pulls himself up again -- he's not looking up, because he can't anything yet anyway -- naturally, this leads to -- A head and rock collision. Gabe's head crashes against a part of the crack, as the passage thins out. He gropes up The passage is narrowing to the point that he can't get through it. Dead end.
Should've taken that left turn at Albequerque.
Gabe backs down, and starts to slide across the side. Wit his back wedged against the rear wall, he uses his feet t push against the forward wall.
Zero visibility -- Gabe can't see what he's shoving towar There has never been light of any kind in here.
blindly pushes to the side, rattled by the difficulty of this in the dark.
It's just like any other side move -- you can't see where the fuck you're going, that's all --
Gabe stops and fishes out his penlight. Turning it on, it clear those batteries haven't gotten any more potent in t last few hours. Gabe shines it to the side.
is fading fast. A match's last gasp is brighter.
exasperated, puts the penlight in his mouth and moves on.
(garbled) Much better.
Gabe inches on to the side. Looks up to see if the crack gotten wider. It hasn't. Gabe mumbles something phonetica near "motherfucker" around the flashlight, aiming it up -
No opening larger than a mail slot --

still cursing, still looking up, still moving to the side he gets the opening he wants, but not where he wants it - The crack suddenly, drastically widens as he moves to the side -- since he's been bracing his back against the wall Gabe falls out of control, twisting around, face down -- Gabe bounces down the walls for several yards and catches himself by bracing his arms and legs against the crack. I now five feet wide as he painfully brakes himself --

falls out of Gabe's mouth and tumbles down, ping-ponging one side of the crack to the other as it tumbles a long, way down -- even after the light is gone, we can still he the penlight's receding clattering against the walls --
is now, literally, in a jam. There are no handholds, no ledges, and the walls are slick. All he can do is remain braced against the crack's walls until his already sore a and legs give out.
Frank is now flying the helicopter -- a body bag is stash the back, and Maggie is in the passenger seat.
(motioning down) Bring it down here.
Maggie --
Just do it, Frank.
The copter touches down -- Frank doesn't turn it off. Mag jumps out with a walkie talkie. Frank makes another try.
Maggie, this is dumb --
No it isn't. I'm going to find Brett -- I don't want to have to talk to his widow too. Fly Evan's body back to base -- I'll call you when I've found Brett. Or Hal. Or Gabe. Or anybody.

Maggie runs off into the snow as Frank lifts off. Maggie quickly through the snow, and it isn't long before she sp multiple tracks in the snow -- they lead toward, and up, buttress. Now she's really confused. But with nothing lef do, she starts climbing up the side.
As we've caught Hal in mid-crossing, he's looking from wh he came -- the opposite side of the buttress, where Trave has a gun trained on him --
unhappily hangs high above the ground from the harness ki provided by Travers --

head_text.subj: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE WIRE

text: Kristel is waiting, also with a gun trained on him. Hal arrives and disengages -- the harness is pulled back.
Kynette pulls the harness back and hands it to Qualen, wh standing next to Travers.
(motioning up) I'm going back.
Look -- this part is nothing, believe me --
Walker should be coming up by now.
Kynette, automatic strapped to his chest, rushes back to buttress' summit.

Gabe is just as we left him. Face down, arms and legs pre against the five-foot gap of the tunnel walls. Carefully, Gabe takes one hand off the wall, gets out his lighter with the other, and ignites it for a look --
Just as the crack has widened below him -- it's wider abo him. More important, it slants at an easy enough angle to allow him to walk up. If only he can get up there.

snaps the lighter shut, pockets it, and readies himself. Gabe steadily "walks" up the vertical passage by bracing himself with one leg and one arm -- then moving the other leg and arm up. Gabe repeats this until he has his hands on the curved ed where the crack snakes into a sideways passage. But there no handholds that will allow Gabe to get a grip and simpl swing over and climb up.
(winded) So much for the easy part.

Gabe takes a deep breath, readies himself, and shoves him away from the wall with his arms, pushes himself into a s against the opposite wall, hanging for a second with no support at all, and he springs from that all into
Gabe lands hard but flat on the passage and immediately s backsliding into the drop, but he digs in with his boots his hands. Safe at last. Gabe carefully stands in a crouc and starts heading up.
Kynette moves to the edge, lies flat, and looks down --
Maggie is climbing up, but she's still some way down -- a the hood of her parka has been pulled over her head. All Kynette can see is what she's wearing: an orange parka.
smiles and hits his headset radio.
He's on the way up. I could hear that jacket before I could see it.
(over radio) Then get the money, kill him and get back here. Now.
(into radio) I'll wait till he comes to me.
Kynette flattens out to wait -- Maggie is coming up fast.
Gabe moves up through the diagonal section -- the crack i starting to go directly upward. Gabe looks up --
It's coated with snow, but not too much -- Gabe can faint make out light shining through up there.
knows the top is twenty feet away. Gabe starts up the eas segment, his back braced against one wall.
is staring down intently at the climber below --
is now almost to the top -- sweating with exertion, she t her hood back.
keys his headset radio again.
(into radio) Bulletin. The climber isn't Walker -- it's a woman.
Gabe, wedged near the top of the crack, is ready to dig through the snow -- but he hears the sound, muffled and distant, of Kynette talking. Gabe strains to hear -- a ba time to come up? Might be.
Maggie, tired, gets near the top and collapses, resting f moment, her arms on the edge -- Maggie looks up and is ve surprised to see Kynette, standing over her, smiling, his aimed down at her.
Rotten weather for a climb, huh? (aims barrel) I have two questions I'd like to trouble you with. Ready?
Maggie stares up, frozen -- whatever she was expecting, i wasn't this.
This first one's easy. Do you know a man named Gabe Walker?
Yes. (breathless, scared) Where is he?
You don't know either? I am sorry. That was question number two. (lowers barrel) Thanks for your time.
As Kynette tightens his finger around the trigger --
appears -- he completes his run toward Kynette's back and kicks him over the edge --
goes flying over Maggie, his shots going wild -- but he catches himself on the rock and comes to a painful but sa halt after skidding down ten feet --

yanks Maggie to her feet and onto the top. Maggie gets a look at Gabe -- his clothes are slashed, he's covered wit cuts, and coated with slime and dirt from the crack. He l like he's just spent a week in Hell. Gabe doesn't react t reaction -- he just grabs her hand and runs.
chooses this moment to show up at the opposite edge -- he fires and automatic BURST at Gabe and Maggie.
Come on --
Where? --
Here.
